item.title: My Week
item.description:
🛠 Visualizing Business Processes and Teamwork

This week we dove into the world of business processes and diagrams. At first, it felt unfamiliar — blocks, arrows, subprocesses… But gradually, I realized what a powerful tool it is. We learned how to create BPMN diagrams and describe real business scenarios.

Our team was given a logistics case for an online store. We modeled the delivery process from order placement to package receipt. We analyzed bottlenecks — including delays during order picking. After introducing automation in two points and recalculating the timing, the process became one and a half times faster! Micro-optimization — but what a satisfying result.

👥 It was our first experience working in a small group — discussing solutions, drawing the diagram together, debating who’s responsible for what. A great introduction to collaborative work.

🎯 The most valuable insight: I’ve learned how to “see” a process, even when it’s not visible on a screen.

item.title: Academic Website with Hugo Academic
item.description:
🌐 Academic Website with Hugo Academic: A Researcher’s Digital Portfolio

In the age of digital communication, every researcher, graduate student, or science-driven student faces a common question: where and how to showcase achievements, publications, projects, and interests? One of the most elegant and modern solutions is to create a personal academic website — a digital business card that works for you 24/7. One of the best tools for this is Hugo Academic (now known as Wowchemy).

🧭 What is Hugo Academic?

Hugo Academic is a theme for the static site generator Hugo, originally created for the academic and research community. It allows you to build a personal site for a scientist, researcher, or educator without needing advanced web development skills.

The platform is tailored for:

  • publications and bibliography,
  • projects and research work,
  • resume and biography,
  • talks and presentations,
  • blogs and educational resources.

🧱 Website Structure

A website built with Hugo Academic resembles a professional portfolio. It typically includes the following sections:

  • About — a short biography, photo, and contact information
  • Publications — formatted lists of scientific works with support for DOI, BibTeX, PDF links, and journal references
  • Projects — descriptions of research directions and activities
  • Talks — a list of presentations, seminars, and conferences
  • Teaching — courses, lecture materials, and syllabi
  • Blog — scientific notes, reflections, and literature reviews
  • CV / Resume — a visually structured resume with optional PDF download

🎨 Why Choose Hugo Academic?

✅ Scientific Standards Support

You can add publications via BibTeX, automatically pull metadata from Google Scholar or Crossref, and display your bibliography with filtering by year or category.

✅ Automation

You can update your site via Git or sync it with online databases like ORCID, Zotero, arXiv, and PubMed — no need to touch HTML manually.

✅ Speed and Reliability

As a static website, it loads instantly, can be hosted on GitHub Pages, Netlify, or other platforms, and doesn’t require a server or database.

✅ Responsive Design

The site looks great on both desktop and mobile devices. Light and dark themes are supported, along with many layout customization options.

✅ Open Source and Active Community

It’s an open-source project under active development with plenty of community support, templates, and documentation available.

🧑‍🔬 Who Should Use This?

  • Young researchers and graduate students — to showcase their academic activity and gain visibility
  • Educators — to organize courses, lecture notes, and learning resources
  • Grant applicants — to illustrate their research trajectory and contributions
  • Science communicators — to maintain a blog or public lecture archive

🚀 How Does It Work?

The site is built from plain text files (Markdown and YAML) organized in folders. You write your content, and the theme turns it into a stylish web page. No need to write HTML, CSS, or JavaScript manually.

Publishing is done via Git — you edit locally, push to GitHub, and your site updates automatically. Especially handy for those already using Git in their academic workflow.

🌍 Example Use Cases

  • Personal websites for university faculty
  • Online portfolios for early-career researchers
  • Showcase pages for research labs and teams
  • Course and MOOC landing pages
  • Blogs on topics like math, AI, biology, and more

💡 Your academic website is not just a page with a photo — it’s your digital identity in the scientific world. Hugo Academic gives you all the tools to present yourself clearly, professionally, and beautifully.

If you’re planning to start a research career, build international collaborations, or apply for grants — creating a site like this is absolutely worth it.

item.title: My Week
item.description:
🧩 SQL and the First Experience with Big Data

This week was all about queries and tables. We began learning SQL — the language that allows you to speak with databases. It was both challenging and incredibly fascinating. At first, SELECT and WHERE seemed like just words, but after a few sessions, I was writing queries with JOINs, grouping, and date filtering.

One seminar stood out: we worked with a customer database from an online store. By filtering by registration date, region, and order amount, we identified the “top” users. The feeling of managing thousands of rows of data was thrilling!

✨ I also attended an intensive workshop on building Customer Journey Maps. We analyzed the client’s path from the first advertisement to the purchase and post-service stages. I realized how crucial touchpoints are and how much digital infrastructure affects them.

💡 The word of the week is “structure”: data structure, process structure, and thought structure.

item.title: My Week
item.description:
🌱 Week 1 — Introduction to Business Analytics and Community

The semester began with engaging lectures in the course “Data Analysis in Business.” The instructor explained how numbers drive management decisions and showed real examples of company reports. For the first time, I truly understood the role of Excel and Power BI — behind every graph lies a whole story.

In practice sessions, we built pivot tables and visualizations. I especially enjoyed a case study on an online store: we worked with real data to investigate why revenue dropped in March. It was inspiring to realize that I’m already capable of making small but meaningful analytical discoveries.

🔥 Another highlight of the week was an evening session with a representative from VK. He talked about how the company digitized its internal business processes, automated customer support, and developed internal IT tools. I loved how he spoke about digital maturity — I want to reach that level one day!

📸 I took a few notes and sketched some diagrams — slowly starting to build my personal “analyst’s hackbook.”
